definition: Imperial College of Supreme Learning, established in 124 BC, and the highest educational institute in ancient China until the Sui Dynasty

sentences.english: Taixue was very important to the political control and the development of culture in the Han Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 太学对汉代的政治统治和文化发展起了重大作用。

sentences.english: The development of the university made Luoyang form the strong atmosphere of study of Confucian Classics.
sentences.chinese: 太学的发展，使京师洛阳形成了浓厚的经学文化氛围。

sentences.english: Han imperial power and the enhanced powers of the decision of the Imperial College is bound to decline.
sentences.chinese: 皇权及大族权力的增强决定了太学势必衰落的命运。

sentences.english: Compared with previous ones, the education system of Song Dynasty is a great innovation.
sentences.chinese: 和前代相比，宋代的太学教育制度有了很大的创新。

sentences.english: At the same time, it also laid emphasis on the selection and appointment of teachers that is done through competition.
sentences.chinese: 同时，也注重对太学教师的选拔和任用，优胜劣汰。

sentences.english: Early tour Yuanyou Imperial College, say industry court building, it is called hold urns.
sentences.chinese: 元祐初游太学，筑堂讲业，名曰抱瓮。

definition: Imperial College (or Academy), the highest educational body in imperial China
Imperial Hanlin Academy, lasting from Tang dynasty until 1911
scholar preparing for imperial examinations (in former times)
academy of classical learning (Tang Dynasty - Qing Dynasty)
to offer a libation/person who performs the libation before a banquet/senior member of a profession/important government post in imperial China
members of the Hanlin Imperial Academy 翰林院, employed as imperial secretaries from the Tang onwards
metropolitan civil service examination (held triennially in spring in imperial times)/Crown Prince's chambers/by extension, the Crown Prince
Imperial scholar from the Ming Dynasty onwards
place where the emperor listened to lectures (traditional)
refers to academics employed as imperial secretaries from the Tang onwards, forming the Hanlin Imperial Academy 翰林院
